answer:
<p><code>.classA.classB</code> refers to an element that has both classes A and B (<code>class="classA classB"</code>); whereas <code>.classA .classB</code> refers to an element with <code>class="classB"</code> descended from an element with <code>class="classA"</code>.</p>

<p>Edit: Spec for reference: <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/selector.html#attribute-selectors" rel="noreferrer">Attribute Selectors</a> (See section 5.8.3 Class Selectors)</p>

<p><code>.classA.classB</code> it means that the elements with both classes name will be selected whereas <code>.classA .classB</code> means that the element with class name <code>classB</code> inside the <code>classA</code> will only be selected.</p>
data.title: What does a space mean in a CSS selector? i.e. What is the difference between .classA.classB and .classA .classB?
